qas.question: What city became the state capital of South Carolina?
Charleston was the state capital of South Carolina until what year?
In what year was the cotton gin invented?
What became South Carolina's major export commodity after 1793?
Who made up most of the primary labor force of cotton plantations?
What city became the state capital of North Carolina?
Charleston was the state capital of North Carolina until what year?
In what year was the cotton gin rejected?
What became South Carolina's major export commodity after 1739?
Who made up little of the primary labor force of cotton plantations?

context: Although the city lost the status of state capital to <a0_0><b5_0>Columbia<b5_0/><a0_0/> in <a1_0><b6_0>1786<b6_0/><a1_0/>, Charleston became even more prosperous in the plantation-dominated economy of the post-Revolutionary years. The invention of the cotton gin in <a2_0><b7_0>1793<b7_0/><a2_0/> revolutionized the processing of this crop, making short-staple <a3_0>cotton<a3_0/> profitable. It was more easily grown in the upland areas, and <b8_0>cotton<b8_0/> quickly became South Carolina's major export commodity. The Piedmont region was developed into cotton plantations, to which the sea islands and Lowcountry were already devoted. <a4_0><b9_0>Slaves<b9_0/><a4_0/> were also the primary labor force within the city, working as domestics, artisans, market workers, and laborers.
